Butterfly Effect: What Kubernetes SIG Security Has in Flight - Ian Coldwater, Independent; Savitha Raghunathan, Red Hat; Carol Valencia, KrolCloud

Kubernetes SIG Security continues to spread security across the cloud native field. Flutter in for updates about what we’ve been up to, featuring VEXing bugs, the perennial third-party audit coming back up, Security Self-Assessments emerging from dormancy to bloom again, (O)wasps, budding new contributors, and collaborating across SIGs to bee better together.

Everything we do as contributors has ripple effects outward. Security is everyone’s responsibility, and every one of us can make a difference.

What’s landing, and what’s taking flight? Come hear the buzz with us, and learn how you can get involved!</article>

items.title: CNL: Kyverno 1.16 — Advancing Policy as Code with CEL and SDK
items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]
items.content: <article>Kyverno 1.16 delivers major advancements in policy-as-code for Kubernetes, centered on a new generation of CEL-based policies now available in beta, with a clear path to GA. This release introduces partial support for namespaced CEL policies to confine enforcement and minimize RBAC, aligning with least-privilege best practices. Observability is significantly enhanced with full metrics for CEL policies and native event generation, enabling precise visibility and faster troubleshooting. Security and governance get sharper controls through fine-grained policy exceptions tailored for CEL policies, and validation use cases broaden with the integration of an HTTP authorizer into ValidatingPolicy. Finally, we’re debuting the Kyverno SDK, laying the foundation for ecosystem integrations and custom tooling, with maturity planned in 1.17. Join this session to learn what’s new, how to adopt CEL policies confidently, and what’s coming next.</article>

items.title: Confidential Observability on Kubernetes: Protecting Telemetry End-to-End - Jitendra Singh, IBM
items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]
items.content:
<article>Don't miss out! Join us at our next Flagship Conference: KubeCon + CloudNativeCon events in Amsterdam, The Netherlands (23-26 March, 2026). Connect with our current graduated, incubating, and sandbox projects as the community gathers to further the education and advancement of cloud native computing. Learn more at https://kubecon.io

Confidential Observability on Kubernetes: Protecting Telemetry End-to-End - Jitendra Singh, IBM India Pvt. Ltd.

Kubernetes observability tools, like Fluent Bit, OpenTelemetry, and Loki, provide deep visibility, but they also handle sensitive data: user identifiers, tokens, and internal service metadata. Even with encryption at rest and in transit, telemetry data is often exposed during collection and processing.

In this lightning talk, we’ll show how to secure observability pipelines on Kubernetes using confidential computing-enabled nodes. We demonstrate how observability components (e.g., Fluent Bit, OpenTelemetry Collector, Loki) can run inside hardware-isolated Kubernetes nodes, ensuring that telemetry data is encrypted at the source and only processed by trusted, attested workloads.

Attendees will learn a practical, zero-intrusion design that combines Kubernetes-native observability tools with confidential compute infrastructure to deliver end-to-end encrypted, trusted observability, ideal for regulated workloads in finance, healthcare, and government.</article>

Connect with our current graduated, incubating, and sandbox projects as the community gathers to further the education and advancement of cloud native computing. Learn more at https://kubecon.io

Lego Bricks for Developers: Turning Insights Into Golden Paths at Neo4j - Jeremy Adams & Luke Beamish, Neo4j

In this talk we are going to discuss how we use engineers' feedback to build a system of reusable “Lego Bricks” at Neo4j. These Lego bricks are composable, team-owned instructions for accomplishing common developer tasks like implementing tracing, metrics, feature flags, or even constructing Argo Workflows.

Inspired by Spotify’s concept of Golden Paths, we combine Backstage Analytics (surfaced by Spotify's Insights plugin), and feedback to guide developers toward proven patterns.

In this talk, we’ll walk through how we use this data and how teams can create their very own Lego Bricks and Sets, and how this model helps us standardise, scale, and simplify the developer journey across our organisation.

Expect practical takeaways for building your own version of Golden Paths with measurable impact.</article>

Sponsored Keynote: Accelerating Innovation: The Evolution of Kubernetes and the Road Ahead - Jago Macleod, Engineering Director, Kubernetes & GKE, Google

In its first decade, Kubernetes earned a critical place in modern workload and infrastructure orchestration - but new workloads and unprecedented scale were pushing the limits. Last year, we highlighted some fundamental gaps in Kubernetes for emerging workloads, and shared Google’s commitment to invest in its evolution.

In this keynote, we will reflect on the foundational role and exciting future of Kubernetes as the leading platform for both traditional and AI workloads. Kubernetes evolved quickly over the past year, due largely to the declarative API, the modular and extensible nature of the platform, and the strength of the ecosystem - and innovation is only accelerating.

With some key new primitives landing recently, and the broader evolution of Kubernetes well underway, we’ll close with a vision of the future and highlight some exciting projects underway.</article>

Connect with our current graduated, incubating, and sandbox projects as the community gathers to further the education and advancement of cloud native computing. Learn more at https://kubecon.io

Sponsored Keynote: From Cloud-Native to Agent-Native: Context Engineering for Kubernetes - Idit Levine, Founder & CEO, Solo.io & Keith Babo, Chief Product Officer, Solo.io

Kubernetes is the leading foundation for cloud-native platforms, but when it comes to agentic workloads, critical gaps remain that prevent many organizations from getting agents to production. These gaps exist because agents and tools are not just containers; they introduce new requirements such as dynamic identity for agents acting on behalf of users, end-to-end observability for probabilistic workflows, and context-aware networking for MCP and A2A protocols. Bridging this gap requires Kubernetes itself to be extended to become a context-aware runtime. Just as platform engineering abstracts complexity for developers, context engineering extends Kubernetes to make AI and agentic workloads first-class citizens. This talk will focus on the key use cases, requirements, and solutions we see in the agentgateway and kagent communities that platform teams must navigate when bringing agents to production.</article>

Thinking Outside the Classroom: Building an Edge Device To Monitor Atmospheric Conditions - Hadijat Sanni & Jubril Oyetunji, Independent

Being in a Nigerian university, depending on what state you school sometimes means that your education falls short in terms of the problems we are exposed to and the topics we explore in class.
To fill this gap we formed NARSDA, a small group primarily focused on astronomy based research, this semester we decided to take our heads out of the cloud and focus on some local problems facing your school.

In this session we will discuss how we built an edge device to monitor atmospheric conditions in our school, how we leveraged Prometheus, grafana and MQTT to collect and generate meaningful insights from the data and finally how we plan on using the data to cut down emissions and possibly save an endangered bird native to our local.</article>

items.title: Breaking the Latency Barrier: Tackling Compute and Network Delay... Kate Goldenring & Sudesh Girdhar
items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]
items.content:
<article>Don't miss out! Join us at our next Flagship Conference: KubeCon + CloudNativeCon events in Amsterdam, The Netherlands (23-26 March, 2026). Connect with our current graduated, incubating, and sandbox projects as the community gathers to further the education and advancement of cloud native computing. Learn more at https://kubecon.io

Breaking the Latency Barrier: Tackling Compute and Network Delay With Globally Distributed Wasm - Kate Goldenring, Fermyon Technologies, Inc. & Sudesh Girdhar, Akamai

Latency isn’t just a backend problem or a network issue—it’s both. Reducing time-to-response means optimizing not only how far your workloads have to travel (network latency) but also how fast they spin up and execute once they arrive (compute latency). Solving one without the other leaves users waiting.
This talk introduces Spin, the open source developer toolkit that uses WebAssembly (Wasm) to reduce compute latency to near-zero. With sub-millisecond cold starts and scale-to-zero efficiency, Spin apps can be built in a local dev loop and then deployed anywhere with no changes to the code. That same application can be deployed to any SpinKube cluster or globally across Akamai’s 4,000+ edge locations. The result is serverless applications that feel instant, no matter where users are.</article>

Lightning Talk: Service Quality Management for Critical Edge Applications - Jaime Burbano, FH Dortmund

Edge applications require high-computing power and low latency responses, while running on resource-constrained devices. Maintaining consistent, high-level service performance is challenging in heterogeneous and dynamic edge computing conditions (server load, network traffic, jitter, etc.). In that situation it is very difficult to ensure stable edge service quality.

We propose an open-source solution that monitors the entire edge chain (applications, UE, network, servers with Kubernetes), analyze the correlated data, plan a service quality action and execute the plan.

The solution has been fully developed and tested with a small set of real-world use cases.</article>

items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]

Lightning Talk: Running Energy-Aware AI Inference on Edge Kubernetes With Kepler - Miguel Rojas, Independent

As AI workloads move to edge environments, it’s critical to balance performance with power consumption. In this lightning talk, we’ll demonstrate how to run a lightweight AI inference workload on a K3s-based edge Kubernetes cluster while measuring energy use in real-time — using only two core open-source tools.

The demo will deploy a simple ONNX Runtime-based image classifier and track its energy impact using Kepler (Kubernetes-based Efficient Power Level Exporter), with metrics collected by Prometheus. No GPUs, no complicated stacks — just a minimal, repeatable setup showing how even small inference jobs can be optimized for energy awareness. Ideal for platform engineers, AI ops, and edge developers interested in sustainable practices.</article>

items.author: CNCF [Cloud Native Computing Foundation]

Connect with our current graduated, incubating, and sandbox projects as the community gathers to further the education and advancement of cloud native computing. Learn more at https://kubecon.io

Securing the Edge: Multi-Cluster Governance With Kyverno on K0rdent’s Fleets - Dolis Sharma, Nirmata & Prashant Ramhit, Mirantis

As organizations scale AI workloads and applications across edge environments, enforcing consistent governance and security policies becomes increasingly challenging. This session introduces a practical approach to scalable policy enforcement across fleets of Kubernetes clusters using Kyverno and k0rdent, with k0s as the lightweight Kubernetes distribution powering edge nodes.

The session covers fleet-wide governance strategies, including dynamic resource allocation (DRA) for GPUs, policy automation in disconnected or constrained environments, and real-world patterns for enforcing compliance in the field.

Through demos and architecture walk-throughs, this session provides actionable insights for those deploying Kubernetes at the edge, particularly in industries like telco, manufacturing, and smart infrastructure. We will also share patterns for integrating policy-as-code workflows and automating Kyverno validation via CI/CD or offline pipelines.</article>

Sponsored Keynote: The Long Arc of Digital Rights: Securing our Open Source Future - Emily Fox, Red Hat

Atlanta is the city that showed the world how principled, community-driven action can forge a more equitable future. The Open Source community is at its own inflection point, where our core principles of transparency, autonomy, and collective responsibility are being tested by new regulations like the CRA and the rapid evolution of technologies like AI. We can learn a lot from our history by leveraging critical principles to guide our response in today’s most urgent security challenges. Digital Sovereignty, an evolution of zero trust focused on autonomy, and the emergence of open source technologies like confidential computing and attestation are closer to making this a reality. As we navigate the complexities of the AI era and prepare for a post-quantum world with new cryptography, we must address critical gaps between technology implementation and the technologists available to do it. We can do this by reaffirming these principles through investment and collaboration to build a more secure and resilient open source ecosystem for everyone.</article>
